importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement of the expulsions from the Communist Party and military, marking a significant development in China's anti-corruption campaign.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The start of a broader anti-corruption drive in the People’s Liberation Army, which has led to the removal of senior military officials like He Weidong and Miao Hua.

keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges.

He Weidong, China’s number two general and a former vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission, is the first sitting general removed from the Central Military Commission since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution.
Miao Hua, the former top political officer of the navy, had been under investigation since November 2023 and was previously removed from the Central Military Commission in June 2025.

The expulsions are part of a wider anti-corruption campaign initiated by President Xi Jinping, signaling a 'cleaning house' to consolidate power and ensure loyalty within the military and political leadership.
He Weidong and Miao Hua are among several senior military officials removed, including He Hongjun, Wang Xiubin, Lin Xiangyang, and two former political commissars of the Army and Navy.
Former People’s Armed Police commander Wang Chunning was also removed from the national legislature in a related purge.
He Weidong has strong ties to President Xi Jinping, having served in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s and commanding the Eastern Theatre, a key region facing Taiwan.
In 2022, He played a key role in planning aggressive live-fire drills around Taiwan following U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taipei.
These purges are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum in Beijing, where new appointments to the Central Military Commission will be made.
Analyst Wen-Ti Sung suggests that the removals allow President Xi to appoint new members to the Central Military Commission, which had been virtually half-empty since March 2025.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, China expelled two top military leaders—He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general and former vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission, and Miao Hua, the former top political officer of the navy—on corruption charges, marking the first such removal of a sitting general from the Central Military Commission since the Cultural Revolution. Both officials had been under investigation for serious violations of discipline and duty-related crimes involving large sums of money. He Weidong, a close ally of President Xi Jinping with deep roots in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces, was also a member of the Politburo, elevating the political significance of his removal. His role in planning aggressive military drills around Taiwan after U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit in 2022 further underscores the strategic implications. The purge is part of a broader anti-corruption campaign launched in 2023, with several other senior military officials also removed. These actions are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, where new appointments to the Central Military Commission will be made, signaling President Xi’s ongoing efforts to consolidate power and ensure military loyalty.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
